documentType: Bureau of Prisons psychology intake and risk assessment
summary: This document contains three Bureau of Prisons psychology service forms for Jeffrey Epstein completed on July 8, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC-NY). It includes an initial intake screening, a risk of sexual abusiveness assessment, and a general administrative note. The intake notes Epstein's denial of mental health history and his calm presentation, while the risk assessment identifies him as low risk for sexual abusiveness in the facility. The administrative note expresses concern about suicide risk factors due to his high-profile case and an upcoming court proceeding.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the Bureau of Prisons psychology intake and risk assessment forms. He is a 66-year-old male incarcerated at MCC-NY on sex trafficking charges, assessed for mental health, adjustment, and risk of sexual abusiveness.

persons.name: PsyD/PhD
persons.context: The psychology provider (Reg #: 76318-054) who conducted the initial intake evaluation and risk of sexual abusiveness assessment with inmate Epstein on July 8, 2019.

persons.name: PhD/Chief Psychologist
persons.context: The chief psychologist who consulted with a doctor at Central Office regarding inmate Epstein's suicide risk factors and issued instructions for monitoring upon his return from court.

persons.name: Drn
persons.context: A doctor at the Bureau of Prisons Central Office consulted by the chief psychologist regarding inmate Epstein's risk factors.

persons.name: Inmate Brown
persons.context: Mentioned in the intake screening in the context of denying any familial history of suicide behaviors or attempts; appears to be a clerical error or reference to another inmate's record.

connections.description: Clinical relationship where the psychology provider conducted intake and risk assessments on inmate Epstein.
The chief psychologist was involved in assessing Epstein's suicide risk and issuing monitoring instructions.
The chief psychologist consulted with a doctor at Central Office regarding inmate Epstein's case.

events.title: Epstein's BOP Psychology Intake and Risk Assessment
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes initial psychology intake screening and risk of sexual abusiveness assessment at MCC-NY upon his arrival. He is assessed as having no current mental health diagnosis (CARE1-MH) and low risk for sexual abusiveness in the facility.

events.title: Court Proceeding for Epstein
events.description: The administrative note references a court proceeding scheduled for Epstein on this date, which could potentially give him 'bad news regarding his legal situation,' prompting suicide risk concerns.

events.title: Suicide Risk Monitoring Ordered
events.description: Following consultation with Central Office, the chief psychologist orders that upon Epstein's return from court, R&D staff and Lieutenants must immediately notify psychology and potentially place him on a watch status for a suicide risk assessment.

keyFacts: On July 8, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was assessed by BOP psychology as having no current mental health symptoms or diagnosis (CARE1-MH) and was calm and cooperative during intake.

The risk of sexual abusiveness assessment identified Epstein as 'Low Risk of Abusiveness' at the facility, despite noting a history of prior sexual abuse perpetration in the community and prior violent offense convictions.

A separate administrative note on the same day expressed significant concern about suicide risk factors for Epstein, citing his high-profile case, sex offense charges, pre-trial status, and an impending court proceeding.
Epstein denied any history of being a victim of physical or sexual abuse, and declined participation in any treatment or programming recommendations, including sex offender treatment.
The document contains a probable clerical error, referencing 'Inmate Brown' in a section about denying familial suicide history within Epstein's assessment.
